message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient had a kidney stone, and the most common type of kidney stone is calcium oxalate. The other options are less common causes of kidney stones.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The CT scan shows a small stone in the left distal ureter, and the patient passed it later. Calcium oxalate is the most common type of kidney stone, accounting for 70-80% of cases. Other options occur less frequently.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the stone in the left distal ureter suggests the most common type of kidney stone, which is calcium oxalate. Hematuria is present in many kidney stones, but only calcium oxalate stones are seen as a common finding with normal serum calcium and phosphate levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and CT scan reveal a stone in the left distal ureter. Among the options, the most common stone type is Calcium oxalate, which constitutes up to 80% of all stones.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has passed a stone, and the most common type of stone is calcium oxalate, which accounts for 80% of all kidney stones. The other options are less common causes of kidney stones.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the patient's symptoms and laboratory studies, the stone is most likely a calcium oxalate stone. Uric acid stones are associated with low urine pH and cystine stones are rare. Xanthine stones are also uncommon and are associated with a genetic disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and CT scan indicate that he passed a calcium stone. Calcium oxalate is the most common type of calcium stone. The other options are less common types of stones.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of flank pain, nausea, hematuria, and a 4-mm stone in the left distal ureter, which suggests calcium oxalate as the most likely answer for the metabolic analysis of the stone. Uric acid can also cause kidney stones, but it's less common than calcium oxalate. Cystine and xanthine are even rarer causes of kidney stones.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has passed a 4-mm stone in the distal ureter, which is most likely to be a calcium oxalate stone. The other options are less common causes of kidney stones.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing symptoms of ureteral colic, which is commonly caused by a calcium oxalate stone. The normal laboratory values for serum calcium, phosphorus, creatinine, and urea nitrogen also support this diagnosis.
